thread.title: Northumberland EU Referendum results: Did your area vote Leave or Remain?
thread.title_full: Northumberland EU Referendum results: Did your area vote Leave or Remain?

author: chroniclelive.co.uk
title: Northumberland EU Referendum results: Did your area vote Leave or Remain?
text:
The video will start in 8 s Cancel Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
People in Northumberland voted strongly in favour of leaving the European Union. 
In one of the last results in Britain to be declared, Leave clocked up 96,699 votes to 82,022 for Remain. 
The turnout in the county was 74.4% with 178,815 votes being cast. 
Brexit campaigners cheered as the results for the referendum were announced at Blyth Sports Centre at around 6am. 
Berwick MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan: “It is a really exciting for Northumberland and the rest of our region. 
“To have 55% vote to leave is a powerful result and shows people want to take back control. 
“I look forward to going back down to London to start the process of us no longer being shackled by the EU.” 
Northumberland County Council leader Grant Davey, who campaigned for Britain to stay, fears the result could have a big impact on jobs and services across the county. 
He said: “It is a very disappointing result for Northumberland, there is no getting away from that. 
“We have 1,200 jobs which rely on EU funding and I think this was a vote against David Cameron . 
“It is now up to the Government to make sure the loss of funding does not affect our jobs and services.” 
Liberal Democrat group leader, Jeff Reid, predicted Northumberland would vote to leave the EU. 
He said: “People in the urban areas are dissatisfied with life, the Government and politics.” 
While UKIP’s Nigel Coghill-Marshall said: “The impact on the fishing industry is a big aspect of it. 
“People do not feel attracted to the EU. We have different ideas to the metropolitan and city areas.” 
Results after 0 of 382 areas declared Waiting for the first results Leave: 1,197 votes (50%) As it stands Britain is set to Remain in the EU
